moves.1. e4 b6: I've been experimenting with Owens Defense.  I don't always like the positions I get.  In this game, Black had no advantage, but finally won in the endgame.
moves.2. d4 Bb7 3. Nc3 e6 4. a3: This move is not bad, but uses a tempo.  White will have to play vigorously from here.
moves.4... Nf6 5. e5 Ne4 6. Nge2 Nxc3: The Black N has no escape squares.
moves.7. Nxc3 d5 8. Be3 Be7 9. Be2 Nd7 10. Qd2: White's position here is good.  There are lots of possible plans, but the pawn on e5 makes it difficult for Black to defend the K.  If I were White, I would be tempted to castle Queenside and use the mobile Kingside pawns to attack.
moves.13. Qe2 cxd4 14. Bxd4 Bc5 15. Bxc5 Nxc5: After these exchanges, I think Black is ok here.
I also looked at Rc4 here, but Nd6 causes problems.
moves.20. Rc1 Bxb5 21. Qxb5 Qxb5 22. axb5: Now material is even, but Black might be slightly better owing to more control of the open file.
moves.22... Rc4 23. c3 Re4+ 24. Kd2 Rxe5 25. R: Now Black is a pawn to the good, still with some pressure on the open file.  There is some urgency to exchange because White can pressure a7 if given time.
moves.28. Kd3 Rfc8 29. Rc2 h6 30. g3 d4 31. Re: Black should have an endgame advantage.  The key is that Black's K has to penetrate to threaten White's pawns.
moves.39. f4 e5+ 40. fxe5+ fxe5+ 41. Ke4 Ke6: This endgame should now be winnable for Black.
moves.42. Kd3 Kd5 43. g4 g5: This freezes White's pawns.  White has only K moves--and Black has the opposition.
moves.44. Ke3 e4 45. Kd2 Kd4 46. Kc2: This is immediately fatal.  The K has to stay in front of the pawn to extend the game.
moves.46... Ke3 47. Kd1 Kf2: On f2, the K controls the e1 promotion square and the game is effectively over.  White resigned.
